name: Bloom Syndrome
aliases: Congenital telangiectatic erythema and stunted growth
description: Bloom syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by short stature, sun-sensitive skin rash (telangiectatic erythema) on the face, increased susceptibility to infections, and a significantly elevated risk of developing various cancers at a young age. It is caused by mutations in the BLM gene, which is responsible for DNA repair and maintaining genomic stability.
prevalence: 1 in 48,000 Ashkenazi Jews; rarer in other populations
symptoms: Increased risk of cancer (leukemia, lymphoma, carcinomas)
prognosis: Variable, depending on the development and management of complications, particularly cancer.
lifeExpectancy: Reduced, with a median age of death in the late 20s, primarily due to cancer. However, with careful monitoring and treatment, some individuals live longer.
diagnosticMethods: Chromosome breakage studies (sister chromatid exchange analysis)

treatmentOptions.name: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (for certain cancers)

eli5Summary: Bloom syndrome is a rare problem where kids don't grow very tall, get a sunburn-like rash on their face easily, and have a higher chance of getting sick and getting cancer. It happens because their bodies have trouble fixing broken DNA.
clinicalSummary: Bloom syndrome (BS) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the BLM gene, encoding a RecQ helicase involved in DNA replication, repair, and recombination. The hallmark features include proportionate short stature, facial telangiectatic erythema with sun sensitivity, immune deficiency, and a predisposition to a wide range of cancers, often at an early age. Chromosomal instability, manifested as increased sister chromatid exchange (SCE), is a key diagnostic feature. Management focuses on sun protection, infection control, cancer surveillance, and treatment of complications. The prognosis is guarded due to the high risk of malignancy.
historicalBackground: Bloom syndrome was first described in 1954 by Dr. David Bloom, a dermatologist, who observed a group of patients with characteristic facial telangiectasia and stunted growth.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Improved understanding of BLM helicase function
recentBreakthroughs.description: Research has further elucidated the role of the BLM helicase in maintaining genomic stability and preventing tumorigenesis, providing potential targets for therapeutic intervention.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Development of novel cancer therapies for Bloom syndrome patients
recentBreakthroughs.description: Researchers are exploring targeted therapies and immunotherapies that may be more effective and less toxic for individuals with Bloom syndrome who develop cancer.
